title.text: IxaMed: Applying Freeling and a Perceptron Sequential Tagger at the Shared Task on Analyzing Clinical Texts

abstractContent.text: This paper presents the results of the Ix-aMed team at the SemEval-2014 Shared Task 7 on Analyzing Clinical Texts.

We have developed three different systems based on: a) exact match, b) a general-purpose morphosyntactic analyzer enriched with the SNOMED CT terminology content, and c) a perceptron sequential tagger based on a Global Linear Model.
The three individual systems result in similar f-score while they vary in their precision and recall.
We have also tried direct combinations of the individual systems, obtaining considerable improvements in performance.

introductionContent.text: This paper presents the results of the IxaMed team.
The task is focused on the identification (Task A) and normalization (Task B) of diseases and disorders in clinical reports.

We have developed three different systems based on: a) exact match, b) a generalpurpose morphosyntactic analyzer enriched with the SNOMED CT terminology content, and c) a perceptron sequential tagger based on a Global Linear Model.

The first system can be seen as a baseline that can be compared with other approaches, while the other two represent two alternative approaches based on knowledge organized in dictionaries/ontologies and machine learning, respectively.
We also tried direct combinations of the individual systems, obtaining considerable improvements in performance.), which can be broadly classified in the following types: • Knowledge-based.
This approach makes use of large-scale dictionaries and ontologies, that are sometimes integrated in general tools adapted to the clinical domain, as MetaMap (Aronson and Lang, 2010) and cTAKES ().
For example, in () the authors show the use of a rule-based approach on the output of MetaMap.
These systems take a training set as input and apply different variants of machine learning, such as sequential taggers based on hidden Markov models (HMMs) or conditional random fields (CRFs) ().
These approaches try to take the advantages of different system types, using methods such as voting or metaclassifiers ( ).
In the rest of the paper, we will first introduce the different systems that we have developed in section 2, presenting the main results in section 3, and ending with the main conclusions.
